settings.text:
Fibromyalgia is a condition which causes widespread pain throughout the body. There is no known cause and can develop due to a number of reasons. It is thought to be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain.

Many believe Fibromyalgia is all in the mind, but this is untrue and is classed as a real condition. Due to Fibromyalgia being able to minic many different conditions, it can be difficult for your physican to diagnose.

settings.title: What can Trigger Fibromyalgia?
settings.text:
Fibromyalgia can be triggered by a number of things, including:

  • Trauma
  • Surgery
  • Injury
  • Physical or Emotional Stress
  • Operation
  • Genitics
  • Enviromental Factors

settings.title: What can Fibromyalgia Mimic?
settings.text:
Fibromyalgia can minic a range of different conditions, making it difficult to diagnose.

These include:

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • MS
  • Lupus
  • Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
  • Anemia
  • Thyroid Disease

settings.heading: What are the symptoms of Fibromyalgia?

settings.text:
Main Symptoms:

Extreme sensivity to Pain

Joint/Muscle Pain -

Fatigue - Extreme Tiredness and Exhaustion.

Never feeling fully refreshed, even after a good night's sleep.

Other Symptoms

IBS or other Digestive Problems

Brain Fog

Depression

Headaches

Chest Pain

Restless Leg Syndrome

Insomnia

Poor Concentration

Anxiety

Rashes

settings.title: Diagnosing Fibromyalgia
settings.text: There is no labratory or imaging test that can be used to detect Fibromyalgia. Instead your doctor will perform a Tender Point Checklist to determine if there is widespread pain. If a patient shows signs of pain in 7 or move areas, and a Symptom Severity Scale of 5, then your doctor may diagnose you with Fibromyalgia.

settings.title: Tender Point Checklist
settings.text:
There are mulitple areas of the body which your doctor may apply pressure to determine how widespread the pain is.

These include:

  • Arms
  • Legs
  • Shoulders
  • Neck
  • Hips/Buttocks
  • Abdomen
  • Back
  • Hands
  • Jaw

settings.title: Symptom Severity Scale (SSS)
settings.text:
The SSS is a measured on your response to 3 different areas of questioning. These will relate to Fatigue, Waking Refreshed & if you have any Cognitive Problems, i.e. Brain Fog.
A score of 0-3 will be given depending on your anwers.

These are:

  • 0 - No Problem
  • 1 - Mild Problem
  • 2 - Moderate Problem
  • 3 - Severe Problem

settings.title: Oral Medication
settings.text:
There is no known cause or cure for Fibromyalgia which can make this condition very difficult to treat. Medication is mainly prescribed to patients to reduce pain and to help with sleep problems.

Antidepressants can be effective in treating nerve pain and treating fatigue.

  • Amitriptyline
  • Citalopram
  • Duloxetine
  • Fluxetine

Antiseizure Medication is used to stop nerves in the brain sending signals to the rest of the body. This type of medication is effective in Fibromyalgia patients because it stops the pain receptors from being able to send pain signals to the body.

  • Pregabalin
  • Gabapentin

Over the Counter NSAIDs can be used to reduce pain levels.

  • Ibuprofen
  • Naxproxen

settings.title: Self Help
settings.text:
Many effective treatments for Fibromyalgia do not come in the form of traditional medication, but in the form of self help. However, this path of treatment is not always suitable for everyone.

The following practices have proved benefical for those suffering from Fibromyalgia.

  • Yoga
  • Tai Chi
  • Accupuncture
  • Massage Therapy
  • Exercise
  • Meditation
  • Physical Therapy
  • Talking Therapies

settings.title: Living with Fibromyalgia
settings.text:
Living with Fibromyalgia can be difficult, but it does not have to stop you from living your life.

The lack of understanding this conditon has, can make you feel isolated and feel like it's all in your head.

Widespread pain and lack of sleep/concentration, may make it difficult to hold down a job, be able to socialise or continue with education.

Adjusting your day to day living, so that it fits within your symptoms can be benifical. Knowing when to stop and give your body the rest it needs is essential.

settings.title: What is Fibromyalgia?
settings.text: Fibromyalgia is a condition which causes widespread pain throughout the body.

settings.title: How did I get Fibromyalgia?
settings.text:
There is no known cause of Fibromyalgia.

It can be as a result of a traumatic injury, such as from a car accident or from an operation.

settings.title: What can I do to help my Fibromyalgia Symptoms?
settings.text:
A doctor can prescribe you medication to help manage your symptoms.

Gentle Exercise, yoga, accupuncture can be very benefical in elevating fibromyalgia symptoms. Self Help Therapies can make living with Fibromyalgia easier.

settings.title: What Triggers Fibromyalgia Flare ups?
settings.text: Lots of different factors can trigger a flare. Stress, Sleep deprevation, Infections and Change in Medication can all trigger a flare in your Fibromyalgia.

settings.title: Is there a definite Test to diagnose Fibromyalgia?
settings.text: No, there is no definite test to diagnose Fibromyalgia. Instead your doctor will perform a Tender Point Test of different areas of the body. If pain is experienced in 7 or more and you have a score of 5 on the Symptom Severity Scale then you may be diagnosed with Fibromyalgia.

settings.title: Is my Fibromyalgia all in my head?
settings.text:
No.

Fibromyalgia is a real condition and is not all in your head.

This condition is often misunderstood by patients and those around them, that make you feel exactly that. However, this is not the case.

There are a wide range of Support Groups, both online and in person for those suffering with Fibromyalgia.

The UK Leading Charity, Fibromyalgia Action, and can offer a wide range of support and advice.
